question.text:
For a body executing S.H.M. :
(a) Potential energy is always equal to its K.E.
(b) Average potential and kinetic energy over any given time interval are always equal.
(c) Sum of the kinetic and potential energy at any point of time is constant.
(d) Average K.E. in one time period is equal to average potential energy in one time period.
Choose the most appropriate option from the options given below :

solution.text: The formula of kinetic energy in S.H.M. is, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>K</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msup><mfenced><msqrt><msup><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></msqrt></mfenced><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> is the amplitude of the S.H.M. the formula of potential energy is, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, so the net energy is defined as, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>T</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>K</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>.</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msup><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> so the total energy is always constant. Since, energy changes from potential to kinetic and vice-versa the average <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>K</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>.</mo></math> in one time period is equal to the average <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi><mo>.</mo><mi>E</mi><mo>.</mo></math> in one time period.
